text:
On tap this was beyond amazing. In bottle the appearance and palate are not as not worthy. 

Still an amazing beer however. And really a true imperial porter. Several are selling high gravity beers as porters... cant say I agree or get this. I would say this is the best imperial porter out there. 

Vanilla toffee, with an end of oak. Down right awesome flavor. Aroma has some alchol.and other flavors. GREAT BEER still!

Bottle from the source. Served at room temperature into my snifter.
Very dark brown pour with reddish tints. A beige head leaves a lot of
spotty lacing. Aroma has chocolate and espresso, with a solid vanilla presence. One part to one part to ... Very nice, beyond possibly being not as strong as one would prefer. Taste is of big bakers chocolate, green coffee beans and sweet bourbon. And, down in the glass, a touch of caramel with a lot more sweet bourbon. Medium-to-full bodied with some alcohol. Not sure if the presence is as much assumed from the flavor or actually kicking in. Finishes long and bourbony sweet, with some bitterness back from the choco/coffee. But vanilla-led. This has some rawness to it. Certainly a white whale, so quite excited. Will age some and retry in a while. Some have compared to KBS - not sure, may have to do a vertical. 16.2

Bottle thanks to motortoddhead. Black pour with a small creamy head that fades to a thin ring. Aroma has a ton of oak and vanilla, nice chocolate and burnt wood, and light coffee too. Tastes very balanced. Oak, vanilla, nuts, caramel, light char, coffee, and a hint of raisin. Very smooth, slightly creamy. Love this.
Bottle. Pours a dark brown with medium tan head. The aroma is roast, bourbon, wood, cocoa. Slick mouthfeel with sweet roasted malt, light booze, toffee with a dark fruit finish. Very nice.

Bottle - thanks to nimble prop! Pours dark black, small tan head, nice residual and lacing. Aroma is bourbon, vanilla, roasted malts, chocolate, oak. Flavor is medium sweet, and light plus bitter, chocolate, vanilla, oak, bourbon, molasses. Low acidity. Medium body. Solid.

[6613-20140815] Bottle. Roasted soya sauce aroma. Black brown cola body with a quick foamy off-white head. Soya saucy roasted grains flavour. Full body. Good but lots of soya. (7/3/8-/3/14) 3.5~
(@ Campground Brewdown 2014, Millmont, PA)

2014-08-15. Black body with a small tan head. 3+ Aroma is richly sweet and bourbony, vanilla. 7++ Flavour is similar, rich bourbon vanilla, sweet dark malt core. 7++ Smooth medium bodied palate, low carbonation. 3+ Simple, but rich. Bottle, 2012 Vintage at Campground Brewdown
Pours pitch black with tan head. Cocoa, bourbon, oak, nuts, vanilla, and come coffee and caramel notes on the nose; follows onto the palate. Very complex, big beer. Finishes with a nice bourbon note.
(12oz bottle) rich clear deep brown,no head. Nose of coffee, umami, beefy, light smoke. Taste of caramel, brown sugar, faded coffee, bit watery, but more Medium on the linger.

25-Jul-11 (12-oz bottle, Bottled 10-Mar-06: Obtained 01-May-06 in trade with hopdog, thanks Steve!)Well, after aging a bottle with a screw-off cap for five years, its no surprise to me that the carbonation is very low; no sound is emitted when the cap is removed. As expected, the clear, dark-brown beer pours with no head. The nose offers chocolate, coffee, prune, wood and a light bourbon note. In the flavor, lots of sweet chocolate bar, cocoa, prunes, coffee, and molasses. The bourbon barrel aging is apparent, but not dominating, with flavors of wood, vanilla, coconut, and a touch of bourbon in the finish. On the palate, its medium in weight, somewhat dry in the finish, and low in carbonation. Overall, this is quite solid. Aging a beer for five years may be too long to some people, but this beer has held up wonderfully.

Bottle at home with friends. Pour is pith black with a small cream head and decent lacing. Big roasty, light bourbon, vanilla, cocoa, coffee beans, caramelly, earthy aroma. Taste is big cocoa, espresso, earthy, semi-sweet, smooth malty, lightly tangy, brown sugary, and dark fruity. Slick mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Great porter.

12oz bottle from Todd. Thanks! 

A: Dark mahogany pour with a very thin ring of light mocha colored head. A decent amount of legs on this one. 

N: A very intense espresso rises up from the nose. Theres some vanilla, and caramel, but its more roasted coffee. Chocolate underpins this, and theres some blackberry and cherry, but its not a rich bouquet of smells. 

T: Sweet and roasty with a slight bitterness. Theres a slight oaken sourness (not infected, just that kind of sharpness). Bourbon runs through this, but its missing an extra dimension. 

M: On the lighter side given how big it is. Still a medium bodied beer, but I expect a more burly malt character to slosh around on the tongue.

O: A solid beer, and Im glad to have tried it. Works well as a day to day drinker, but Id appreciate more dimension throughout because it seems more like a porter and a half than an imperial porter.
Bottle share at KBBS day, nice dark pour with a thin tan head. Aroma of chocolate and roasted malt. Taste was a bit subdued with barrel, alcohol and a bit of tartness coming through.
Bottle shared by Colin.  Dark brown pour with a tan head.  Dark fruit and booze aromas.  Wow, all kinds of bourbon with muted syrup, dark fruits, and  malt notes.

Bottle shared on the RBWG 2013 bus. Pours black with a creamy, tan head. Fairly fruity stuff, lots of cherries and raisins. Tons of sweetness, light earthy bitterness. Full bodied with fine carbonation. Lightly syrupy. Moderate warmth to finish. Some chocolate, more dark fruits. Good.

I had such high expectations... The nose is alright... Smells of funky cheese...? Some bourbon and dark chocolate, plenty of vanilla... Flavor is awesome, with loads of  bourbon and vanilla. Not so much chocolate.. Actually, yeah, loads of awesome milk chocolate!! Loads!! Great medium body, and super drinkable!

dark brown with amber edges. light head
Loads of cocoa and some raisins
taste is decadent. Smooth, roasted some burnt coffee and cream. Its like a carbonated / boozy coffee stout. very very good!

Bottle on the RBWG bus 
Appearance: Dark brown with a medium sized beige head and good lacing 
Aroma and flavors of dark malts, vanilla, oak and toffee 
Nice and tasty

Bottle on the bus at RBWG.   Thought I had tried this, but apparently not.  Well I tried it again, damnit.  Another solid imperial porter/stout from Tyranena--its been a while since I had once of these.   Lots of barrel, nuttiness, coffee, and cocoa.  Basically what youd expect from a well done ba stout/porter.  Thanks whoever shared this.

355mL floating around the RBWG bus. Hell yeah. Pours an opaque inky black. Rockier, mocha foam. Nose is pickles, black olive, sugar, licorice root, sweet rye bread. Taste is buttery, creamy, whipped cream oil, chocolate cake, frosting, sugary dessert, mild alcohol heat. Palate is creamy, dense, dessert heavy. Very nice.

From a bottle shared at RBWG! Commercial description has good notes on appearance, aroma, and taste, so I will tell you this, it is big and ballsy. Very good, but Im not sure where the line between imperial porter and stour is drawn.

Aroma is mostly dark roasted malt - coffee and a faint roasted meat note. There is a hint of dark chocolate as well. After the malt fades you pick up the barrel character with some vanilla and nuts as well as a slight oak note. 
Pours black with dark brown highlights on the edges. Just a thin light brown head that quickly recedes to the edges where it lingers. No lacing and medium sized legs. 
Flavor starts out with sweet chocolate and toffee then the coffee shows up adding a mocha like character. There is a light dark fruit note in the finish but then the barrels character sets in. The finish has bourbon along with vanilla, coconut and nuts. There is a slight oak note as well. The alcohol in the finish is nice and clean. The bitterness is fairly low in relation to the malt notes. 
Mouthfeel is medium full bodied with medium low carbonation. The astringency is low but present and the alcohol warmth is moderate. 
Overall this is a really nice porter that has integrated nicely with the bourbon barrel characteristics. The alcohol isn't too hot and the barrel shows through more than the bourbon. Very enjoyable beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pour out of 12 oz bottle, thick black pour with creamy tan head, aroma brought notes of big caramel, toffee, nice roast, nuts, hints of bourbon, lots of oak in there, some dark chocolate and roast in there.  Taste is a nice mix of roast, chocolate, and coffee, slight dry oak and bourbon in there, hints of nuts, caramel and toffee, finishing sweet, slightly dry.  Nothing over the top, but nice and balanced.

12/1/12. 12oz bottle thanks to nulledge! Black pour with a nice khaki head. The aroma shows nice wood, light bourbon, vanilla, and a hint of tartness. The flavor has chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, wood, and again the beginnings of a sourness. This might be on its way to infection (or a bad bottle), but it is tasty right now.

Bottle via Sloth! Black in color, think mocha colored head that faded quickly... Strong lacing left on the glass. Nose of booze, vanilla, coffee, toast, roasted malts and nuts... The vanilla shines through intially... nice roasted malts, light coffee, toasty/toffee. Body is a little on the thin side, easy to sip on. The alcohol is well hidden. Overall: Good imperial porter. Salute to my friend BJ.... may he rest in peace.
Bottle. Pours dark with a tan head. Aroma is bourbon, caramel and malts. Flavor is a blast of bourbon followed by smooth caramel, malts and some vanilla. A very nice beer. Glad I was able to try it.

Bottle courtesy of the Cheeseman.  Pours a black cola with a medium sized tannish-light brown head.  Aroma of sweet milk chocolate malts, toffee, light hazelnut, vanilla, coffee, toasted oak chips and light bourbon.  Taste of milk chocolate malt, toffee, coffee, light vanilla, mild bourbon,  hazelnut and oak wood chips.  Very nice blend of flavors.

On tap at scofflaw. Been wanting to try for quite some time... Pours a deeper cola black hue and topped with a creamy light khaki head reducing to a small ring around the edges of the glass... Smooth vanilla mild silky bourbon nose with chocolate malt accents... Flavors have a long lasting sweet bourbon presence with lots if residual sugar it seems. Lighter bodied overall with chocolate and cocoa notes throughout, a fair bit nutty.Finishes way too sweet and the body is a tad too thin, more than a tad actually.

12 oz. bottle. Im really excited to try this one. It pours dark brown with a very small tan head. The aroma is very nutty with hints of bourbon, cocoa and pumpernickel bread. Pretty nice. The flavor is more of the same. Bourbon influence is pretty big, but not overly alcoholic. Nuts, dark bread, caramel, cocoa, vanilla, wood and coffee. Very nice and well put together. Worthy of the high rating.

pour is opaque dark brown with a tight creamy brown head. Nose is heavy roast coffee, notes of bourbon and chocolate. Taste is bourbon up front, light wood, notes of dry chocolate and a touch of coffee rind, a bit charred in back. Body is thick and rich up front but thins a little and back, soft carbonation, becomes a touch sweet in finish.

Bottle shared by MrPickles...thanks Andy! - Pours deep black with a ring of tan head. Bourbon heat on the nose, vanilla, hazelnut, chocolate, and some medium roast malt. Taste is smooth. Nutty chocolate, powdery cocoa, vanilla, and toffee notes. Smooth and full in the mouth. Good stuff.

Got this as an extra from somebody... Thanks bro, whoever you are.  Pours a subtle almost black with inky red edges.  Almost no head.  Aromas of chocolate, barrel, salty pretzels.  A little edgy on the first sip. The bourbon taste boarderlines on the ridiculous. Amazing chewy bourbon character. Fuck me, this shit is blowing my mind.  So salty, so chewy, so much bourbon.  Fucken hell. This beer is everything a barrel aged imperial beer should be.  Attenuated, complex, alcohol masked, barrel character, smoothly drinkable. Fuck this Is good shit.

12oz bottle pours a deep brown, mostly black with some creamy, beige head.  Aroma is nice and inviting, vanilla, caramel, malty, brown sugar, a little light coffee, cream soda, a little brown bread.  Flavor is sweet, malty, some milk chocolate, vanilla, a little wood, some coconut, some dark fruit.  Full bodied, sweet finish.  Super drinkable.
UPDATED: OCT 30, 2012 Delicious vanilla-y porter. Coffee in the flavor and smell. Thing but not too much. Barrel adds some heat but it isnt bad. Def wish it was distributed.

On tap at the source.  Deep brown-black with tan head.  Big time nose.  Big barrel vanilla, cream, brown sugar, and faint coffee/roasted malt.  Flavor is beautiful coffee and cream with sweet vanilla and vanilla wafers, and light licorice.  Fades to a slightly acidic roast malt and light cocoa and coffee.  Medium on the palate.  Great barrel qualities that cannot be understated.

12oz bottle, 2012 release, courtesy of the one and only motortoddhead. pours a rich, dense, brown that sits black in the glass topped by a thick, creamy, beige head that leaves smooth sheets of lace. aroma is wonderful with heavy notes of vanilla, hazelnut coffee, toffee, and burnt caramel backed by cocoa powder, toasted oak, subtle bourbon, and cinnamon rolls. flavor is delicious as well with notes of dark chocolate, toasted oak, spent coffee beans, pralines, and maple backed by subtle notes of bourbon, dark fruits, and coconut cake with vanilla icing. palate is rich and smooth with a creamy mouthfeel and a lingering finish of coffee, cocoa, and bourbon. overall, a world class barrel aged porter.

Jet black with a one finger head that lasted a minute or so, then dissipated, leaving some lace.

Oak, bourbon, chocolate, vanilla, roasted malts, just a smidge of burnt and coffee character rounds out the aroma.   

The taste brings out more of the burnt, chocolate and vanilla flavors.  Bourbon tops it off.  Theres a nice bitterness that balances out the sweetness well.  Perhaps some dark fruits too (plums, cherries, raisins). 

Body is slick, sweet, and thick, alcohol is obvious and warming.

A very nice imperial porter.  Delicious.
Amazing how you can smell the type of bourbon barrel that each brewer uses.  Nice burnt sugar flavor.  A bit like a creme brulee.  Love it.

On tap at Tyranena 9/29 in the tasting room, pours pitch black with a huge vanilla head with lacing through out the glass, the aroma has a ton of chocolate and fudge mixed in with the roasted malt, the flavor has an awesome amount of chocolate on the front end with some caramel and coffee in the finish, the bourbon comes through nicely as well and doesnt take over the entire beer by any means, very smooth and creamy mouthfeel, awesome all around.

9/24/10 from dakine. Another one from my want list!

It pours dark orange porter brown with a few bubbles on top.

Lots of bourbon and spice in the aroma and flavor but not so much that it becomes distracting other characters include smoke, fudgey chocolate, roast, vanilla, ash and a slight sourness on the finish. Soft bourbon lingers in the aftertaste. 

Crisp, easy to drink, well made porter (seems to be a delicious trend from these guys). Nice. 8/4/8/4/17

Ein sehr eindrucksvolles Bier, das mich besonders durch den Marzipanartigen Nachgeschmack begeistert. Auch dieses Bier ist sehr voluminös und schwer zu beschreiben, man sollte so ein Bier selber mal getrunken haben. Im Mittelteil machen sich, kurz bevor das Bier ins marzipanrtige übergeht, auch noch Karamellnoten breit. Gerne wieder! 	 
Test vom 7.1.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 12,12,11,15,9,13 - 12,55

Bottle shared by Dak  thanks - didnt think I would get to try this one!  Pours mohagany with a thin tan head.  The nose is bourbon, coffee and chocolate.  The taste is the same with some molasses thrown into the mix.  Nice beer and zero oxidation even at its age.

From dstructo.  Quite a treat.  Black pour, rich brown head.  Nice chocolate covered bourbon cordial aroma.  Flavor is so smooth and still remarkably declicious.  NO oxidation.  Light barrel, bourbon, vanilal, caramel, toffee and chocolate.  This one gets a WOW!

Bottle from a trade.  One of the best Tyranena has to offer and only outdone body devil over a barrel.   Pours a black body with a coffee tan head.  Malty chocolate, oak, vanilla, bourbon notes, hints of whiskey wood and some brown sugar.  A modest liquorish etoh warming with a rich etoh warming.  Awesome!  Very happy we stopped by after dark lord day, despite the horrible sunburn.

In short: A big toffee/chocolaty porter with well integrated bourbon character. Excellent beer. How: Bottle 12oz. Consumed oct 2008, age unknown (1+ year old). Received as a bonus in my too many in-person DLD 2008 trades. Forget from whom. Huge thanks to that person anyway. The look: Very dark brown (almost black) body topped by a very small tan head. In long: The lightly roasted nose has some bourbon barrel along with the usual vanilla side-kick. Body is full and the soft carbonation gives it a creamy/viscous sensation. The main flavours are lots of toffee, milk chocolate, bitter black chocolate, some vanilla and some bourbon (less bourbon than expected). Almost nothing in the way of fruity flavours. Moderately sweet. Alcohol well hidden. One of the too-few example of well integrated bourbon barrel, present but not overwhelming. Good beer. Try ordering this beer in Harlem by calling its name out loud and youll see a lot of people raising their shoulders.

This poured dark black in color with a thin head that faded away.  Aromas and flavors were of chocolate, bourbon and crème.  This was medium-bodied, smooth and rich in the midpalate.  It was very engaging and quite enjoyable to drink.  Given the great balance this is one I could drink again and again.

(Bottle, thanks to wetherel) Pours black with brown edges and almost no head. The aroma holds tones of mild aromatic, spicy and medium roasted cold coffee up front with tones of gravel, tar and mild jalapeno oil. Good maltiness. Medium sweet caramel/fudge, liquorice, nuts and chocolate notes alongside light hints of vanilla from the oak. Just a whisper of dark fruits. The flavour is well balanced with notes of caramelly/toffee-like malt, nutty/vanilla-ish oak and dry coffee roast. Sweet dark fruits in the undertones. The mouthfeel is soft, full, velvety and light oily. A medium sweetness lingers but the coffee dries it out a bit. Medium bodied. Not that complex but the balance is perfect.

Hugely dark, rich porter.  Mocha, baking chocolate, light vanilla and nut, and overwhelming alcohol make up the flavor profile.  The alcohol doesn’t overwhelm completely though, and actually enhances the other flavors.  Very delicious.

Impentrable, iunky black, creamy, tossled tan head on top. Very nice. 

Bourbon hits the nose at first. That mix of charcoal and molasses, sweet elixir mixed with heady booze. Some candyish qualities meld with woodiness, but little porteresque characteristics remain. Not complaining, though... 

Lets taste, shall we...Bam, bam, bam! Thick chocolate meets blackstrap molasses, brown sugar, tar, anise, tree bark, ...what else? leather, maple sap...much deeper than the "caramel, toffee, vanilla, toasted oak, hazelnut" listed on the label...maybe Im just tired of those words. 

wow, this is a wicked mix on the tonque...these brewers really did go wild, didnt they? 

Quite a treat this guy. Loved it, and highly reccomend it.

Big Coffee, heavy body, hint of bourbon which I generally dont like but it was barely perceptible I didnt mind it at all.
buy it again
Very interesting aroma, almost bitter. Sampled this at Dark Lord day 2008 in Munster at FFF. Darker then most american strongs. Flavor is chocolate, bourbon, and burnt malt.

Bottle from kp around Jan 2008.  I really appreciate this bottle Keith.  Thanks!  Tasted with WeeHeavy, Cyn, and his friend.  Great aroma.  Some malty chocolate caramel aroma.  Black color.  Mild carbonation.  Flavor is dryish.

Beer 10 of Officially the Best Thursday in Beer ever in the existence of my life.  12ozer shared with Wetherel and my GF Cyn and Wetherel provided the bottle.  Porus dark brown/black with a ring of light brown.  Nose is rich and bold and pretty much grade A huge it is big.  Taste is chocolately bourbony with a slightly tartness to it.  Big Malt Big Roastyness and overall very very good.  I like this brewery and their crazy beers, some how bottled in 12ozers.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2015 Bottle shared by kmweaver.  Nose of sharp buttery Jack Daniels, cocoa and roast, with a similarly buttery flavor of greenish/fresh toffee, coffee grounds, chocolate malt and char.  Falls apart a bit on the back, never really all that thick, but still very delicious and rich.  Finishes slightly sweeter than it begins, with a sweet vanilla, toffee and caramel bourbon note.  Good stuff.

(12oz bottle, thanks kmweaver) Clear cola/dark brown body with small tan head.  Aroma is moderately sweet, Bourbon/vanilla, bittersweet chocolate, light alcohol.  Taste is moderately sweet, chocolate/cocoa, some vanilla, light caramel.  Smooth medium-full body.  At least at this point in the aging, the barrel aging is nicely complementary rather than dominant.

12oz bottle, courtesy of kp.  Thanks, Keith!  Pours a very dense, dark brown color; light tan head with fine-bubbled lacing.  Pleasant, toasty vanilla, slightly warming bourbon, and semi-sweet chocolate in the aroma; some nougat and nice woodiness coming through; generous aroma without being overly sweet.  Relaxed carbonation.  Tons of viscous toffee, bourbon, dense nougat / caramel, and bittersweet chocolate at the forefront; nothing overly sticky; some oily, creamy nuttiness coming through; the barrel aging is very nicely integrated into a solid chocolate and nougat core; nothing hot, nothing overly sweet, and nothing close to boozy.  A nice surprise.  Lengthy, caramel and nougat and dark chocolate in the finish; a slight warming bourbon character throughout.

12 oz bottle from someone.  Pours a thick, deep rich black color.  Aroma is insane - with lots of roasted malt, bourbon and oak.   Flavor is really nice, but there is an odd sourness at the end that is kind of distracting.   This would be the only flaw I can find in this beer.  Had this sourness not been present this probably would have been a 4+ rating.
06 GABF RB tasing Thanks MIBRomeo! Aroma is roast, dark fruits, and oak. Flavor is roasty, oaky, and winey.

12 oz bottle. Black with a big, dense, brown head. Deep, roasty malt nose, some raisin and coffee, rich chocolate. Excellent lace! Mildly dry, bittersweet flavor - chocolate, vanilla and light bourbon, accented with a snappy coffee. Baking chocolate bitter finish. Exceedingly smooth body. Just... wow!

Pours a near pitch black with brown around the edges.  Absolutely no head to speak of.  Smell is lots of bourbon and some roasted chocolate notes. Taste is much of the same and boy is it good.  There is a nice roasted flavor profile coming from the coffee.  This is without a doubt my favorite Tyranena offering.  Definitely needs to be brewed again.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2008 Name: Whos Your Daddy? Bourbon Barrel-Aged Imperial Porter
Date: 05/24/2006
Mode: Bottle
Source: Roadtrip

solid black, thin fine brown head that can be stirred up into producing a bit of lace that quickly dripps back down the glass, 
sweet bourbon aroma with hints of oak, vanilla, and chocolate, 
thick creamy velvet body, 
light sweetness, mild bourbon character that grows and blends well with the nice rich chocolate, nice roasted character that provides the light bitterness, eventually the bourbon takes over but is not out of control, hint of alcohol, 
-------- />
Name: Whos Your Daddy? Bourbon Barrel-Aged Imperial Porter
Date: 06/12/2007
Mode: bottle
Source: tasting
Vintage: 2006

bourbon character is much stronger and induces a fruity character, 

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 10/10; Overall: 16/20
Rating: 3.9/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: **4

Aroma of oats, chocolate, a touch of bourbon and a tiny bit of oxidation that smells a bit like minerals.  Dark brown in color, pretty much black.  Flavor is really good, I taste coffee, chocolate, touch of oak and bourbon, vanilla, some rich molasses and some type of spice in the fairly dry finish.  Texture is excellent, super soft and creamy, it coats the mouth without being overly sweet like many imperials. Oak and bourbon are very subtle. This is excellent.  They should brew this again.

Pours out black with a light tan head that retains decent and leaves some lacing as well. Smell is outstanding; chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, French roast coffee, and a little molasses. Taste opens with some vanilla that leads right into some chocolate, toffee, and coffee notes. Its not done there though, there is also some oak and bourbon as well as vanilla. Both smell and taste are 6 out of 5, just amazing. Lower carbonation and full bodied makes this an excellent sipper. I could sip on one of these every night, I just wish I had another so I could enjoy this masterpiece again.

Dark Brown Color with Tan Head. Bourbon, Rich Malts, Vanilla and Oaky Nose. Medium to Heavy Bodied Beer. The Main Flavor Characteristics are Bourbon, Chocolate and Vanilla..with a Nice Bourbon Warming Rising Up and a Bourbon Dry Roast Aftertaste. Very Smooth and Well Put Together, Albeit Simple Ale. One of the Breweries Better Offerings.

Picked up single bottle at The Coffee Grounds in Eau Claire, Wisconsin. Pours a clear, dark dark borwn brew with a small, short lived beige head that dissolves to a fine film. Aroma of chocolate with some bourbon, oak wood, and a touch of vanilla. Taste is full bodied, smooth and silky feel with soft carbonation. Finish is sweet and smooth with a slight toffee aftertaste. Tasty!

Modest retention of a dark tan head, eventually fully receding. The black body looks weighty. The timid aroma is comprised of chocolate, whiskey, vanilla, licorice, roasted malts and a faint hint of espresso. The flavor is nearly identical, with a pleasant addition of soft fruity hops and a whisper of earthiness. Sweetness is light to moderate, bitterness is the same. Alcohol is well masked throughout. The finish is smooth and creamy, leaving behind hints of chocolate cake icing and orangey hops. Mouthfeel is thinned from the time in the barrel, but not thin overall. Medium bodied, lightly carbonated. Very tasty, but it isnt the knockout I had expected.

Imperial Porter:  Vintage 06.  12oz bottle.  A very opaque dark drown.  Creamy looking, no head.  Dark malt aroma with a bit of alcohol in the nose.  WOW!  Very creamy body.  Ton of vanilla.  A bit of toffee.  Taste has a very chocolaty flavor and coffee in the distant finish.

Appearance: Pours a nearly opaque, near-black body with a thin, khaki-colored head.

Smell: An unmistakably bourbon-esque aroma, with full notes of vanilla, burnt toffee, brown sugar, and smoke.

Taste: Rich, velvety chocolate taste combined with vanilla beans and the smooth, subtle taste of bourbon. Lesser hints of coffee and anise. Finishes with a bit more bourbon and a light roastiness.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied, with a perfectly smooth, creamy mouthfeel. Low carbonation.

Drinkability: Its a treat to finally come across a beer that didnt allow the bourbon barrel-aging to totally crush the load-bearing malt flavors underneath.
06  Pours a deep black color with a light brown head.  Aroma is burnt wood, vanilla, some coffee, and a hint of bourbon.  Flavor is lots of cream, burnt wood, coffee, and some bourbon.  Good beer.

Courtesy 1FastSTI. Black/dark brown with dark brown/ruby edges, small off white cap. Smells russian style, like a giant piece of good-n-plenty along with a strong dose of vanilla, dark chocolate, marshmallow, subtle oak- great nose. Similar flavor adds more chocolate and a bit of coffee. Full body, smooth. Excellent.

Opaque black. Smell is rich malty sweetness that includes vanilla tones, roastiness and bourbon. Just a hint of a dairy-like porter smell from the roasted malt. Bourbon and vanilla come thru in the taste along with a nice roasted flavor and some cola-like sweetness. The smell is very inviting and the roasty and sweet flavors balance each other nicely. I can feel the alcohol strength but it is very well hidden in the taste and smell, not sure if the bourbon scents cover it, but it is well balanced. Creamy medium body, this beer really hit the spot.

Bottle. Very dark reddish black colour with a nice creamy head. Lovely aroma of sweet chocolate, coffee, caramel and hints of alcohol. Nice flavour of bourbon, chocolate, coffe, caramel, vanilla and roastedness. Very smooth and good balanced.

Sample from 16 fl. ounces bottle. Pours orange/amber red. Aroma is aroma hops with a touch of sweet malt. Taste is wellrounded taste of aroma hops and malt profile with sweet platform. has nice smoke note. Finish is soft malty with a touch of bitterness

Thanks to MIBRomeo, my July Secret Santa. Pours almost black with a foamy, tanned head. Smells wonderfully of bourbon, vanilla and funghi. Sweet with lots of vanilla/wood flavors. Nice bourbon touch. Full bodied. Lowish carbonation. Long finish with vanilla again and a slight touch of funghi.

Bottle thanks to Sunevdj. The aroma is dusty corn, wood, vanilla and a bit of roast. The taste is light roasted, vanilla, bourbon, wood and chocolate in a Medium to full body with a soft vanilla finish.

12oz bottle- A black body with a small ring for a head and an aroma of toffee, caramel, sweetness, and bourbon aroma. Taste of bourbon, vanilla, sweet maland a nice finish with some chocolate. Great tasting porter.

Bottle.  Pours a very dark brown (almost black) with a medium sized beige head.  Aroma is roasted malts, coffe and a sniff of the booze.  Flavor is roasted malts, some nuttiness, plums/prunes and a small amt of the bourbon.  Very smooth and easy drinking.  The BA is pretty subdued, making for a tasty beverage.

Im really beginning to like these guys.They dont make a whole lot of the ultra great brews but they do a nice job on what they do.Nice dark brown color,small tan head that faded quickly leaving little behind.The aroma was pleasant.Malty and and bourbonesque with a mild showing of some chocolate and maybe a hint of caramel in there as well.The flavor is fantastic.Malty,dark chocolate taste with some hints of vanilla in the middle and the bourbon manages to come through nicely without being the dominant flavor.Nice brew all around,and well worth having a few more for later.

12 oz bottle, thanks to captaincougar for this! I cant believe spector and moejuck were the last ones to rate this when we didnt do it at a tasting.  Pours black but still can see through it. Aroma of this is a lot of bourbon, some chocolate and roastiness. Flavor was very smooth and easy to drink. Rich and creamy also and very tastey.  Flavor had some vanilla notes and a little roastiness. Very good beer.
Roasted malt and bourbon stand out in the aroma.Pours black with a thin tan head.Very smooth chocolate and some nice bourbon make up the flavor.Very full mouthfeel with a smooth chocolate finish.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2007 Thanks to brewblackhole for the bottle!  Light bourbon barrel scents with some sweet roasted malt in the aroma.  Black body with a brown head.  Full, smooth, creamy palate is very nice.  The taste is exactly like the aroma, plus more roasted malts.  Glad to have a BA brew that doesnt go overboard on the barrel aspect.

Bottle. Very nice, sweet aroma, a lot of vanilla. Black colour, no head. Very distinct vanilla flavour and a very late vanilla aftertaste. Some alcohol is felt. Very nice for a while, but very rich. Great, though.

Black colour with a light brown head. Roasted malty, light coffee bitter aroma with hints of some chocolate sweetness and a note of wood. Roasted malty flavor with some vanilla sweetness and a fruity note. Roasted light bitter finish.

(sampled at the Düsseldorf RB gathering) Black coloured with a short tanned head. Sweet toast-malty, slightly vinous aroma with strong notes of vanilla and traces of cacao and marzipan. Moderately sweet flavour, full bodied with a smooth mouthfeel. Roasted taste with caramel, vanilla and liquorice. Sweet and slightly bitter finish with marzipan in the aftertaste. Pleasant.

A deep red beer with a disappearing brown head. The aroma is sweet with notes of alcohol, sweet soy sauce, and roasted malt. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of chocolate, roasted malt, and sweet soy sauce, as well as hints of vanilla and coffee.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Pours a clear, dark brown with a vague tint of red and a small, light brown head. Very delicious chocolate aroma with notes of vanilla and bourbon. Smooth, rich body with notes of coffee, chocolate and bourbon. Very delicious indeed - yum. Courtesy of madsberg. 120207

Bottle.
Clear brown coloured with a beige head.
Roasted aroma of dried fruits, wood and vanilla.
Sweet and roasted flavour of vanilla, wood and dried fruits.

Bottled (Thx to davidP for the trade). Pitch black coloured. Dense light brown head. Sweetness, vanilla, light fruits and chocolate in the aroma. The vanilla barrelnotes not as distinct as in other ba beers. Same goes with the flavour. Quite balanced sweetness, roast and vanilla. Some choconotes. Is full bodied. Very smooth and easy to drink porter. A bit too smooth maybe. Definately a great brew, but I would love a little more edge.

12 oz. bottle via trade with CaptainCougar - Pours a clear dark brown color with a 1/2 finger thick tan head which faded quickly.  Faint spotty lacing.  Aroma is coffee, oak, and light roasted malt.  Very nice.   Flavor is great.  Its semi-sweet chocolate, light coffee, oak, and vanilla.  Palate is a little thin, but smooth.   Medium body.  Alcohol is well hidden.  An excellent beer.  Thanks Tom.

12 oz bottle.  Whips up nice with a good pour.  Ebony with a brown head that leaves sheets.  Smells like dark chocolate, brandy, wood and leather.  Hints of cigar complete the old den image. Stong bourbon; coffee and vanilla cream.  Flavors are pronounced but not overwhelming.  Brown sugar gets sour; black olives.  Medium body, minimal carb, slight alcohol, gets sticky.

From a 12oz Bottle.  Dark, chocolatey black colored pour with a thin, wispy head of toasted marshmellow.  Lots of Mexican vanilla wafts from behind a thick malty curtain, coated with layers of toffee, whipped chocolate nougat, and supple caramel coffee.  Almost a touch of chocolate covered salty pretzel lingers intriguingly as well.  Medium bodied, lightly carbonated mouthfeel.  Loads of white chocolate and vanilla wash pleasingly over the palate.  A touch of balancing hops linger in the final smack with some very mild roast coffee.  Highly unique flavor profile - very light, like a silky Danish chocolate mousse garnished with a splash of coconut.  Thanks, Tom!

Thanks to Ughsmash I believe for this one....Pours out black with tiny little wisps of a head. Aroma is of chocolate and bourbon. The taste is very complex, yet well balanced. Chocolate, oak, molasses and coming through the strongest was a nice note of bourbon with slight alcohol on the finish. Great beer from yet another brewer I wish I had more access to.

Bottle shared with dickinsonbeer, thanks!  Pours just about black.  Aroma is alot of chocolate, some bourbon, notes of vanilla.  Taste is sweet chocolate, bourbon, oak, vanilla and a touch of alcohol.  Flavors are all well balanced.  great beer.

Brewblackhole told me he wouldnt be able to get this for me and then upon opening my package there it was, staring me in the face. So many thanks. Ok, this was an incredible porter, reminded me of an impy stout in a way. The color is deeper and blacker than most porters and has an almost non existent brown head. The aroma was incredibly dense. Wow, sooo much going on. Bourbon is the definite powerhouse here, but it gives way to alcohol, sweet chocolate and molasses, vanilla, and roasted coffee. Absolutely wonderful. Man alive, tastes as good as it smells. Again strong bourbon taste, very whiskeyish, oak, vanilla, chocolate, roasted coffee, and alcohol. Simply amazing. The palate was a step down from its sensory attributes but still nice, needs to be fuller and thicker. The finish is warm and dry, feels like bourbon gone down neat. Probably one of my favorite beers of all time and Im sad that it was a limited release.

Aquired the trade with brewblackhole.  I cant believe that this is a porter.  The color was deep chocolate/black.  The head was medium brown, but barely there.  The bourbon smell was very distinguishable in the aroma.  There was alcohol, molasses, chocolate, and oak smells as well.  The flavor was bourbon, alcohol, caramel, chocolate.  The flavor peaked after the initial bourbon taste.  The palate had a kick to it and the finish was warm.
This beer has a very good flavor and aroma, but could definately benefit from a creamier, more textured body.

Bottle (@Ddorf Gathering): Black coloured, tanned head, sweetness, smoke and wine in the nose, the spirit of Bourbon is detectable; smoked taste, sweetish-bitter, coffeeish finish. A conoction lagered in Whisky barrels: thats an incestous affair.........

Bottle courtesy of the one they call Ugh. Very dark brown, mahogny edges to light, huge beige head. Looks a tad thin. Spotty lacing. Huge vanilla and bourbon nose, done just right, not offensive at all. Tons of residuel sweetness. Again plenty of bourbon and vanilla in the flavor. Getting a certain rootbeer flavor through the middle, whatever it is Ilke it. Some coffee in a very clean finish. nice creamy mouthfeel. Pleasantly surprised by this brew. Much thanks Jason!!!

Bottle.  Aroma first whiff, reveals a touch of bourbon and vanilla oakiness.  Poured a dark brown.  Flavor was quite tasty, woody vanilla, bourbon and caramel and bitter chocolate. I chewed this trying to figure it all out.   Palate is right on, not too thick and not watery.Finishes remarkably for all the flavors in there.  Overall I enjoyed this immensely.
Düsseldorf gathering, been keeping this one to share!  One word for this one, Vanilla! Bourbon is there too, but vanilla is what jumps out. Anis, oak, raosted malt, great beer!!!

Bottle at the Düsseldorf Gathering.  Black, muddy body.  Pours like sirupe.  Lightly brown head.  Aroma of liquor, vanilla (very much, like theres a whole vanilla bean in your glass) and very strong malts.  Very complex and interesting aroma.  Very intense, bitter-sweet flavour.  Very complex flavour and well balanced.  Very nice!

Dusseldorf Gathering, Bottled. Bourbon and vanilla aroma. Very dark brown color, light brown head, good lace. Bourbon with loads of vanilla, licorice and moccha. I dont like bourbon but this beer is so well balanced that it isnt annoying me at all. Very good beer.

12 oz bottle, via JCapriotti.  Pours a very dark brown colored body under a small tight bubbled brown head that fell to a thin creamy film.  Aroma is caramel, roast, chocolate, light alcohol, some coffee, and moderate bourbon.  Flavor is quite unusual, theres alot of caramel with the usual chocolate battleing for supremacy over the vanilla and light bourbon notes.  I really like the interplay between the two.  A great balance has been struck here, just the right amount of bourbon barrel influence.  The vanilla goes great with the caramel.  Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with a slightly oily texture and great soft carbonation.  Very mouthcoating, leaving a finish that lingers quite long.  I really liked this beer.  Great balance with the barrel influence, and very well hidden alcohol makes this extremely drinkable.

Bottle from Paul (blankboy) Thanks!  Pours out a dark brown to almost black color without any head at all.  Smell is mostly bourbon notes, some vanilla, some oak.  Taste is sweet with coffee, chocolate, oak, bourbon, vanilla.  Pretty sweet, and pretty thick too.  Took quite a while to get this one down, but it was good.  Seems like this would be really good without the barrel addition.  Worth a shot though, and id drink it again if given the chance.  Thanks Paul!

Bottle: Black with a dark tan head. Aroma, bourbon, chocolate, coffee, oak, rich malts. Flavor, rich chocolate and coffee, vanilla, some bourbon. Theres a little bit of heat on the finish, full bodied, some nice lacing. This is a damn good beer.
GTM  06 Draught. Wonderful, rich, sweet bourbon aroma. Dark, black, almost opaque body. Thin, off-white head, large bubble. Wonderful bourbon notes.
Bottle. Nose-sweet grape and plums. Taste-grape, coffee, cigarette smoke, fig, very light wood, light toffee, chocolate, peanut dust.

This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a small sized head of foamy fine to medium sized bubbles that was long lasting and left behind a opaque no visible carbonation black brown colored body. The mild aroma was mild toffee  smoky mild chocolate and dark malt. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and strongly tingly at the fading finish that left behind a vinous oily dark malt aftertaste. The flavor contained notes of mild hops deep caramel toffee mildly vinous and dark malt. Delicious and one I would certainly buy again.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2007 Bottle... GABF RB Tasting 06...This beer rocks! ... Nearly pitch black ale (ruby, against bright light) with a mid-sized, creamy, tan head. Excellent retention. The aroma is a swirl of milk chocolate, vanilla and light bourbon with a touch of coconut. Tastes like a chocolate milk shake with a thimble-full of bourbon added. Sweet, but not cloyingly so. Full-bodied and silky with soft carbonation. Chocolatey, vanilla finish. World class beer! Thanks go out to MIBRomeo for sharing the bottle!

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2007 Black as a lawn jockey with the head of a 50s cheerleader.  Sweet on the tongue like honeybees breakfast.  A note of bourbon thatd make the parsons wife blush - a good overall effort by these guys, who have disappointed me in the past.  Like the nutty chocolatey flavors, not as off the charts as some similar efforts by others.

Bottle. Small tan head that mostly diminished, poor lacing, opaque, no visible carbonation, and a black hue with a tiny bit of brown on the sides of my glass. Dark malts, chocolate, vanilla, bourbon in the nose. Flavor was bourbon and not overly done, malt, vanilla, chocolate, and a whisper of caramel. Smooth, dry mouthfeel. Medium body.

Med/large choco brown head, retention is good lacing is coating. A pitch black Porter! Light whisky in the nose, a touch of vanilla, smoke and a little fried wiring, me like! Body is medium with an oily mouthfeel thats creamy smoooth. Gentle Bourbon flavors on top, light roast, chocolate and vanilla ramp up as it warms. Notes of caramel, wood and cherries arrive. Finish is dry, roasty and woody with notes of ginger and subtle whisky flavors. A well done balancing act. Alot of flavor from such a small bottle! Props to footbalm for laying the smacketh downith upon me with this little/BIG jem! You rock Eric!! I need more!!!

Great porter. I taste significant licorice note but apparently no one else does. bourbon, vanilla, woody, not too sweet. complex. With their bitter woman IPA, bourbon aged ale,... this is a great brewer.

A dark pour w/ a thick tan well laced head.  Aroma is definatelly alcoholic some burnt malt touches of vanila a good amount of chocolate and definate bourbon notes.  Palate is full rich and creamy.  Flavor is full of chocolate, light coffee, bourbon notes with hints of wood.  A bit over the top on the alcohol note but pretty good.

Bottle purchased at Rileys, into Olympia stemmed glass.  Opaque warm brown with a smallish but dense tan head.  No lacing to speak of, but racing is deep and dense.  The head revives easily when the glass is swirled.  Smells like brown sugar and bourbon, but the latter is not too dominant since its balanced by aromas of cherry and bakers chocolate.  Creamy thick in the mouth, and syrupy coating in the finish, this beer is more about texture than flavor.  Flavors are most intense in the finish, where the hops are tangy and balance a completely unsweetened bakers chocolate.  Despite syrupy texture, this is never cloying, and manages to achieve dryness late in the finish.  Bourbon increases its presence as the beer warms.  Solid.

Sample at Indy tasting Dicks 96th - Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, and dark malts.  Pours like cola with a small head and decent lacing.  Flavor is chocolate, vanilla, oak, and more chocolate.  Palate is smooth.  Very tasty.

Thanks to JPDIPSO for this one.  Pours very deep black with uniform 1-finger brown head.  5 for appearance.  The aroma is big roasty malt, big oaky bourbon, some molasses, nuts, cacao, Ovaltine, and cherry.  Id say 9 for aroma.  The taste is roasty malty, very oaky bourbony, with a big cacao/chocolate syrup/molasses trifecta, and some vanilla.  The palate is rich and malty, but seems to get a bit lighter as it warms.  If you cant appreciate this beer, then you really need to join the Bros., and discuss topics such as how Anheuser-Busch is making improvements in their brewing process, and how Augie Busch is really a nice guy if you are a hot blonde gal with big tits.

Pour is black with a nice dense tan head...smell is rich chocolate and vanilla with hints of smoke...taste is sweet roasty chocolate and slight alcoholic vanilla...great mouthfeel...thanks footbalm...a real surprise treat

(A BIG THANKS TO FOOTBALM FOR HOOKIN THIS UP)pours a nice black body with red highlights.head was a dark brown and left nice lacing on the glass.the aroma was a nice mix of grahm crackers,chocolate,vanilla,and spice.flavor boasted much of the same with a huge (but not overdone) oak finish.palte is complex but smooth,and the mouthfeel is on the medium side.simply awsome,that sums it up the best.

Chestnut black. Uneven-edged ring of fluffy beige foam. Cola, vanilla taffy and chocolate fudge comprise a large portion of the nose. Faint toasted wood, unripe plums, and bourbon. Prickly carbonation tickles the palate. Pungent roast dominates the initial flavor before morphing into a brisk wall of char. Velvety chocolate fails to take foothold due to the fuzzy carbonation. Yeast and soggy grains muddle the flavor significantly. Some of the bodys girth drops off as it takes on a lightly vegetal flavor. Unripe plum acidity lessens much of the richness, though a fluffy nougat note persists. Alcohol lends dryness, but is well masked. Despite the abundance of  char, wet grains find their way into the finish and taint much of the more-pronounced malt elements. It takes so much more than simply tossing a beer in a bourbon barrel to achieve greatness. Key flaw here is the carbonation, which is far too hard, loose, and fuzzy for my liking. On top of that,  theyve chosen to strip the soul from the beer by filtering it to death. Yes the aroma is okay (obligatory vanilla, wood, and chocolate are all  present), but the base beer doesnt offer anything overly enticing. Just not a whole lot here to hold my interest.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Pours a pitch black color with a smallish tan head.  A smattering of lacing is left behind.  Aroma is chocolatey vanilla with a mishmash of coffee thrown in for good measure.  Full bodied and coating to the palate, lower percieved carbonation level.  Rich flavors of cocoa and vanilla, a bit of tannic oak.  Quite tasty, I wouldnt turn this one down if offered!!  To repeat Springslicker, this isnt a baltic??

12 oz bottle special thanks to Kramer17801.   Darkest dark pour with no head.  Hardly any bubbles at all.   Aromas were very roasty malts.  Coffee and chocolate.  Very pleasing.  Flavors were more darkness.  Toffee and more coffee.  Nuttiness too.  Many of these big porters are indecernible from a stout, but this one does good to keep the porter characters.  Dustiness on the finish.  Pretty darn good.  Awesome Jason...

Thansk to kp for this one!
I got a weak pft when I lifted the cap so I poured this one right down the middle and got a small head of creamy tan to form. The small head fell quickly into a very dark brew. I usually dont look for lace in anything other than Belgians but this made beautiful patterns on the sides of the glass that made up for a weak head.
Rich, sweet, milk chocolate covered cherry candy aroma came easily when cold. As it warmed, coffee then massive vanilla notes appeared. 
The flavor is sweet and complex. I really like this one! Is this not a Baltic Porter??

Bottle from Styles, thanks man. Pours a dark brown with little head. The aroma is bourbon, chocolate, molases, some roastedness. The flavor is bourbon, dark bitter chocolates, brown sugar. Medium body, slightly oily texture.

12oz bottle acquired in trade. Poured a dark black, with red edges, and a smaller sized tan head. Aromas of vanilla bean, chocolate, caramel, bourbon, and light roast. Tastes of vanilla, chocolate, caramel, and light wood. Smooth body. The barrel aging was done nicely on this one - it complimented the beer. Midly sweet with a very light bitter finish.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2006 Huge chocolatey sweet aroma. Flavor was super smooth chocolate, some toffee and coffee and toast. Normally beers aged like this taste like foul whisky to me, but not with this one. Really good and unbelievably smooth. I liked this a lot, it was delicious.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown with a thin brown head.  Aroma of chocolate and various roasts with slight vanilla and Bourbon.  The first sip is vanilla and hot Bourbon with little else, but as it warms the Bourbon fades to the background and gets rounded out by a good amount of roast flavors along with wood notes.  Well done.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2006 12 oz bottle

I finally had my one bottle after this disappeared from the shelves.  Its   too bad really because as it turns out I loved the way this one was made.   Hopefully Tyrenana will make it again at some point.

Aroma / Appearance - Deep black in appearance with a thin oily tan   head.  A creamy mixture of vanilla, bourbon, malt, coffee and cherries   greeted my senses with a subtle mixture of hazel in the background.  It was   very inviting; I could have sat there all night soaking in the rich scents.

Flavor / Palate - A full creamy mouthfeel dense with flavors hit my   senses from the second that the liquid passed through my lips.  Along with   a tinge of bitterness I was able to pick up a smooth combination of malts and   hops.  The bourbon was well balanced; it did not overwhelm my tastebuds at   any point.  I was able to pick up coffee, black cherries, hazelnut, caramel,   toffee and a fleeting woody taste.  Every sip was well balanced - at no point   did it merge into something other than a sublime experience.  Even the finish   was dry and creamy, leaving me wishing I had another bottle.  Snap this up if   you find it - you wont be disappointed!

Yum! Lots of chocolate and bourbn notes stuck in this aroma. Its just seems sticky and tatsy and I havent even poured the damn thing yet. There was no head on top of this thing and it really was basically midnight oil black. The two over powering things in this beer were the bourbon and toasted malts. If you look closely, rather taste closely, there is vanilla, roast, wood, alcohol, some grilled meatyness, and a bit of fruit. This is full of flavour, creamy, filling, and at the same time it has the ability of drying the palate and begging you to have more. Wow, Im certianly impressed.

Bottle, provided by Clark VV. 4/6/06. Good nose, Chocolate, fruity, dairy, coffee, bourbon, coconut. Cloudy brownish black color, good head and lacing. Sweet bitter flavors, like aroma with chocolate and bourbon being most pronouced. Medium body, creamy oily mouthfeel, bitte rdry finish. Tasty brew, tad brash, would be nice to know how it ages.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: bottle-deep chesnut-chared brown with a fizzy tan accent around the rim of the vessel.  Sweet broubon hits the nose with notes of vanilla bean, chocolate, char and sharp woodsy alcohol.  flavors start out bourbon mostly with notes of hazelnut, chocolate, vanalla, and lots of alcohol.  My first thought of this beer was the alcohol was well hidden.  i dont think that so much now.  The bourbon here is not really that over-the top, just not well integrated into this beer as it could be.  body is a little lite and lacks overall mouthfeal/complexity.  finish has notes of caramel, dark chocolate, alcohol and vanilla.  As it warmed, a minty chocolate akin to andies candies came out in the finish.  a pretty good version of the style, but definately a little rough around the edges.

Pours exceptionally black with a moderate head.  Aromas of chocolate, caramel, whiskey and wood.  Lots of caramel/toffee flavors, with some chocolate and very mild coffee, oak, vanilla; a little whiskey and a mild alcohol burn.  Sweet & rich but drying; effervescent.  Nice barrel aging, decent body.

12 oz bottle courtesy of The_Enemy. This beer pours to a deep brown to black color, with a tight white head that fades, and a soft carbonation. The nose on this beer is fantastic, with big aromas of dark chocolate, coffee, vanilla, and oak. The palate is soft and fat on the tongue with flavors of dark chocolate, coffee, mild roast, vanilla, bourbon, and oak. This beer finishes with more wonderful dark chocolate, coffee, and vanilla, then ends with a slightly warming, bourbon/oak flavor that lingers. Very impressive Imperial porter, and a very impressive use of the bourbon barrel to give this beer even more character. A great beer from a great brewery.

This porter pours an eclipse black color from a 12 oz bottle. Small sized white foamy head. Aroma is chocolate and coffee with a touch of bourbon and wood. A medium bodied porter. Malts are fruity, chocolate and sweet. Hops are slightly spicy and earthy. Touch of bourbon and wood, mostly in the aftertaste. Very smooth and mellow tasting porter. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

a most excellent porter.  chocolate and malt and some tinges of alcohol in the aroma.  flavor is chocolate chips and cookie dough, with some vanilla and oak flavors accenting the bourbon.  smooth with coffee, carmel, and some toffee as well.

Got this in Madison. I have tried a couple times now and I like it more than I thought I would. The black body was topped with a tan colored head. The aroma was bourbon with vanilla sweet caramel and coffee. The taste was coffee with dark chocolate. There was also some vanilla and oak. Good and interesting.

Bottle graciously provided by Richlikebeer at the Jimmack 06 Invtl. Dark brown, almost black color with a small tan head. Aroma of bourbon, dark roasted malts, vanilla and oak. Flavor of the bourbon was more subdued than I expected, for which I am grateful. Roasted malts, dark chocolate and vanilla round out the flavors.

Heemer brought this brew down to share at Noogfest II. At first, I thought the name/label was cool; however, I didnt have high expectations. Upon my first sip, my tastebuds welcomed the rich flavors of coffee, chocolate, cream, and hazelnut. The alcohol was very warming and the bourbon flavor wasnt overpowering, making this an excellent brew Id love to enjoy again (which I am presently doing). This is strange -- I cant stand bourbon, but I love this brew! Thanks, Eric -- Whos Yo Daddy?!

Black, thin head, decent lacing. Pleasant nose of roast, vanilla, chocolte, bourbon and a smidge of the alcohol. Medium bodied, smooth, almost creamy, nice porter roastiness, vanilla, the barrel adds some character to the brew. Somewhat assertive hop bitterness develops into the finish. This is tasty, maybe the bourbon aged stuff is growing on me. Drink on boys.

Jimmack Invitational 06. This poured a black body with a small tan head. Smells like a tootsie roll. Taste is excellent. Most bourbon beers have been too much, but this is a great compliment. Chocolate, woody vanilla. Slight alcohol presence. Great brew.
This big boy porter pours a ruby black. This aroma is full of cocoa and a touch of butterscotch. The bourbon is evident, but not overly powerful. This is great stuff.

thanks goes to Ughsmash for this. poured black with a tan head that left some lacing. aromathe bourbon came out strong, than out came the bourbon, than hints of coffee with hazelnut cream in it, some hints of malts, toasty,flavor, wow the bourbon I had the make sure I didnt pour some jack into the glass, vanilla, with hints of chocolate and malts.I can not believe this is only 8% abv like the label says whos your daddy.
The bourbon barreling is not too bad with this one. Still get notes of chocolate ,coffee and molasses but this brew seems a little thin. I like a porter to feel more than water on the tongue.
12oz bottle Pours out black black black. With a dark tan head. Has a very nice bourbon bite also with some almond joy. Great over all. Thanks Indiana_Red

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2007 Bottle pours a very dark brown with a rich dark tan head  Actually had the bubbles going down syndrome.  Very rich woody, chocolately woody, notes with also some notes of sweet purple grapes.  Flavors of sweet chocolate and the burbon flavors really come through.  Plenty of residual sugars and softly carbonated.  Lates slightly smokey trailer with some tootsie roll hints.  A wonderfull example of the style. A big thanks to Captain Cougar for this gem

Bottle: Jet black with a light brown head.  Aromas of brown sugar and liquor (must be from the bourbon barrels).  I didnt smell much of the typical smoky, charcoal aromas.  Surprised by the taste -- I liked the bourbon and the woody flavors.  Fairly thin feel that you would expect.  Delicious!  Thanks Indiana_Red!

DL06:  Poured a clear dark chestnut color with a thin off-white head.  Nice aroma starts with vanilla and then some light bourbon, and chocolate.  Sweet and malty.  The flavor started with some light bourbon.  then some cola, vanilla, and roasted malt.  Mild warming sensation.

Thanks to pailhead Pours a dark deep brown to black with nice tan brown head that dissapeared quickly. Aroma was big with liqorice then the chocolate aromas had become present. Flavor was amazing and well balanced with vanilla chocolate. NIce toffe finish.. Nice brew indeed ..

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2006 Bottle:  Courtesy of Phillip via an in person trade at DL Day.    Great chocolate and vanilla aroma with moderate black licorice and light coffee.  Pours a dark brown with no transparency and a small tan head.  Lots of chocolate, caramel, and vanilla flavors up front. Finishes with an  even mixture of bourbon and coffee.   A very well done bourbon aged beer.  Too many overbearing bourbon beers seem to making their way into the beer geek market and its nice to come across one that is done correctly.

Bottle and served in my GL snifter: Pours a deep brown topped by a rich creamy tan head and left very good lace. The aroma has notes of blueberry, roasty and burnt malts, flowery and aromatic hops, chocolate, vanilla, toffee, tobacco and sadly an initial off-aroma of floor polish or it could have been a 10.  Boy does this start rich and sweet with lots of vanilla, mocha, toffee, and brown sugar upfront supported by a twang of bourbon. Some acidic bite midesection before a lightly peated smoky finish. Once I adjusted, it was not so bad but it took me by surprise in the beginning. The mouth feel is lush and oily with a biting bourbon finish, moderately warming.   Just a little less sweetness and this would have been easily a 4+ in my book, the bourbon characteristic of vanilla may add to the massive initial overtone. Rumor has it that this is more than reasonable in price.
cloudy dark brown body with a grey head. roast coffee nose with alcohol. a mocha flavor with a strong cream and sugar taste.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry & Dave B. -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours deep brown, almost black, with an average size diminishing light-brown head. Wonderful aroma of oak, bourbon, dark fruit, vanilla, malt, chocolate and more -- very complex and a pleasure to smell. Flavour is predominently chocolate malt and bourbon with some smoke and vanilla added and some light hops and alcohol in the finish -- tastes great! Medium to full bodied, syrupy mouthfeel. Im not always a fan of Bourbon in beers but this one is just right -- I love this beer!

Bottle (12oz).  Shared with blankboy and Dave B, my bottle via trade with JCapriotti - thanks man!.  Poured almost impenetrable ruby-black with an average light brown rocky diminishing head. Aroma - wow! - rich oaky/vanilla bourbon sweetness, lightly smoky/peaty dark chocolate roast malt, light cherry and nuts in the finish.   Taste is even sweeter (made me think of a fresh can of play-doh!), thick malt, bourbon barrel character but peaty dark and sweet chocolate overriding all of it, some light hops try in the longish finish where the alcohol finally emerges some ... solid.  Mouthfeel is sweet, thick, syrupy, complex - awesome brew, not as in-your-face with the bourbon flavour as the Bourbon Barrel stout.  Yum!

So what is the name of this?  "Whos Your Daddy?" or "Brewers Gone Wild!"?  No matter, its still good stuff.  Pouring out almost jet black with an ample tan head, this gave off aromas of chocolate, bourbon, anise, vanilla, some espresso, a little coconut.  Rich and robust in the mouth.  Smooth and silky.  The flavor was deep and rewarding.  All the elements of the aroma joined for a sometimes sweet, sometimes bitter, sometimes alcoholic, but always delicious taste.

Pours deep, dark brown with a moderate tan head.  Aroma is subtler than a lot of the bourbon-barrel beers.  You can smell the bourbon, but also the other boubon-related aromas (vanilla, oak), as well as other malt aromas such as chocolate and dark roast coffee.  In the mouth, its also subtler (as you would expect) than the BB stouts.  The flavors mirror whats in the aroma, and in the understated complexity is its value, as opposed to the bigness of something like the Goose Island Boubon County Stout.  I think Im starting to lose my enthusiasm for the bourbon-barrel brews, but this was a nice mellow example of how to do it without letting it totally take over.

Chief Blackhawk meets George Dickel.  This porter has a surprisingly mild aroma that barely hints at the flavors to come.  Loads of caramel malt, then whisky and vanilla dominate.  This is bold stuff.  I thought that the barrel aging worked; close to , but not quite, over the top.  Creative, tasty and fun to drink.

Ah Tyranena, how I love your special releases. This reminded me of Dark Knight in many ways, except this sells for a mere fraction of the price and, frankly, tastes a lot better. Theres no over the top bourbon notes on this as there is on Dark Knight. Instead, theres a great balance of bourbon and porter. On the nose, lots of chocolate and vanilla leading into maple syrup, molasses, more vanilla, nutmeg, and mace. A finish that goes on and on. Well done!

Pours black, with a brown head. Aromas are bourbon, chocolate, and roasted malt. Flavors are bourbon, chocolate, roasted malt, and vanilla. Body is creamy, but a little thinner than I would have preferred. Thanks to Ohio Dad for this bottle.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2007 Pours a deep black hue with a decent lacing and head.  Aroma of vanilla and chocolate.  Intense body and mouthfeel where you definately know it was barrel aged.  The wood also imparts a wonderful vanilla character with mellow creaminess that balances perfectly with the chocolate malt.  Overall, an excellent example of what barrel-aging can do to a big beer.

thx to ughsmash for this one. 
Beautiful vanilla aroma. Pours black w/ a big cocoa colored head
Lots of chocolate & vanilla flavor w/ a hint of roastiness on a medium body.
Niicely done

Wonderful brew. I was very excited to get some of this and Im glad I have another bottle of it to drink later. Poured a very dark brown with a thin mocha head. Smell was hard to get but smelled of chocolates and vanillas. Good marriage of tastes though. Good solid bourbon taste up front with hazlenut and chocolate in the end. A little lacking in the roastiness a porter should have, but still damn good. Slick and a little oily, good mouthfeel. Drinkability is really good. At about 8%(according to the brewery) its not that bad on the alcohol. I could drink this every night if so inclined. Cant wait to have more of this in the future.

Deep black with a small, brown fizzy head.  Aroma is oaky with a hint of semi-sweet chocolate.  Flavor is fantastically complex; big taste of coffee up front with a smooth vein of toffee, caramel and creamy vanilla.  The bourbon is more pronounced as it warms but its definitely there.  Finishes strong with hazelnut and dark chocolate.  Rich, complex and incredibly satisfying.

Pours mostly opaque with a thin tan ring of head.  Has a rich, complex, bourbony dark chocolate malty aroma.  Starts with lots of sugary vanilla sweetness, some toasty caramel malt and more bourbon oaky flavor toward the sweet, lightly warming finish.  NIcely-balanced, but has a touch too much artificial-tasting vanilla flavor.  Im looking forward to their other barrel-aged releases.

Courtesy of The_Enemy

Aroma features sharp roasted malts, coffee and bakers dark chocolate...aroma wise I didnt smell any bourbon until after I had tasted it and trhe beer warmed a little. Deep black in color with a two finger thick head that is constant as the northern star. Rich coffe and chocolate in the fore followed by a LOT of vanilla and an almost Frangelico like liquor flavor. The bourbon is amazingly well integrated into the rest of the flavor palate. There are dark fruits some coconut notes as a result of the meshing of the vanilla, oak and toasty malts. Very lingering aftertaste of chocolate, bourbon and vanilla. Very tasty and well realized barrel aged beer.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2006 12oz bottle.One of the best applications yet of the bourbon barrel-aging process. Not as subtle as their Rockys Revenge Bourbon-Barrel Brown (in which they only barrel-age a portion of the stock), but still very well-integrated flavors. (On this point I strenuously disagree with a number of reviewers who feel the bourbon-barrelization overshadowed all else.) Aroma is slightly vegetal -- the only knock I can think of for this beer -- but this subsides as it warms. Other aromatic characteristcs are the molasses, maple, hazelnut, toasted grain, vanilla; sniffing this beer is almost like walking into a gourmet coffee shop. Bourbon-barrel-aged characteristics are prominent, adding molasses, oak, vanilla and a mercifully judicious bit of bourbon. However, the porter base is not at all lost, contributing its own smokey, caramel, toffee, toasted grain, chocolate and nutty elements. Full-bodied, velvety-smooth creamy palate. As with their less bold but still intriguing Rockys Revenge, this is bourbon-barrelization done right. Seven bucks for a 4-pack of this?? Youve gotta be kidding. Only in Wisconsin do they brew stuff this good for this cheap.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2007 Bonus bottle! from StewardofGondor consumed with OldGrowth on 4/6/06Head sticks around for a minute or two and then fades to partial cover and eventually a ring.  Burnt sienna in color, atop a deep crimson, transluscent (at first) body, that settles out with transparent clarity.  Light, spotty lacing left behind.Aroma is heavy on the barrel, at first.  Dry wood tannins pile in, with tons of coconuty-bourbon notes.  Faint note of alcohol at first, fully passing.  Quite dry and tannic, but as it breathes, fudgy cake emerges rather triumphantly, adding some depth.  Alcohol passes, as said, while the tannins lay off.  Behind them, however, is only light fudge and chocolate.  Thats really the extent of the malt depth.  Though, near the end of the glass, after fully warming, I am getting a smoky, charred wood note from the barrel.  No roasted malt, not really any crunchy, earthy barley.  And even more lacking are the fruits.  Almost zero fruitiness.  No hops, no yeast.Flavor is woody, dry, moderately tannic but sweetens considerably towards the end.  More German chocolate cake.  Very Zywiec-like, actually.  Would almost think this a Baltic porter minus the roast (though Zywiec is very light on roast too).  But it dosent have an ale yeast fruitiness to it, though I imagine it is an ale yeast.  Some dark plums are about the extent of that.  Coconuts on the end, accentuate the barrel character and dont really bother the malts.  The texture is lightly chewy, sort of in between on filtration.  Not too heavy, but could be less.  Malts evolve, somewhat, with graham crackers, adding a crusty, lasting quality.  Dry tannins definitely hold back the sweetness and alcohol is well concealed (I hate it when alcohol is used to balance).  Ends with simple chocolate and easygoing barrel character.  Low carbonation.  A simple man, with simple pursuits.

Bottle: Black in color, dark chocolate edges, moderate to large frothy dark beige head, fairly nice lacing.   Huge vanilla and graham cracker nose.   Slight cocoa, chocolate, and bourbon.   Seems fairly sweet.   Sweet bourbon on the tongue, vanilla, graham cracker, and even a bit of mlk chocolate.   Very smooth, well balanced, with very little bitterness.   Mouthfeel is smooth, body is moderate to thin. &nbsp Remains very clean tho.   Too easy to drink.   I just wish I knew what the ABV was.   I am a sucker for Bourbon anyways.   Thanks Jason for this one, and an extra freebie of this!

picked this gem up at Steves in Madison last week.  black on the pour with a ruby edge.  nose is wonderful aroma of chocolate, coffee, vanilla and caramel.  aged to perfection the barrel has melded the flavors so one does not overpower the other.  a delicious treat!

12 oz bottle courtesy of The Man, DavidP, poured at cellar temperature into a Corsendonk Christmas Ale glass.  A dark tan head of moderate duration, finely bubbled, tops the sunless body....the nose at first quite faint, just mild licorice and vanilla-whiskey, chocolate coming in late in the game along with a touch of espresso, rich toffee  and fine whiffs of grass.....the flavor is quite lovely, rich chocolaty-caky with mild hints of the barrel and again some licorice, little to no alcohol apparency until quite warm (cellar temp is great for this one), and some nice orange liqueur/ bitter citric hops towards the finish, with a slightly drier, mineralic texture to wind it down....rich, velvety mouthfeel with a touch of oiliness but mostly lots of thick black malt, roasty and bittersweet throughout, never verging on either syrupy or oily and thus near-perfect......Im with the yea-sayers on this one, and honestly I must just not be that sensitive to whiskey/bourbon flavors, because this seems pleasantly mild and balanced to me.....a delight.

Pours deep brown and sticky, with a fast, tan head. Props to the crayon font and cartoon on the label. Big alcohol affront... Southern Comfort covers all in the aroma, and SoCo is anathema to me. Seems like somebody forgot to tell these guys to  empty the whiskey barrel before adding the beer.  Chocolate/cherry flavor with vanilla. Lingering fruity-sweet aftertaste despite thin alcohol astringence. Definitely a beer that would own you in large quantities.
